criteria.name: Market Share
criteria.description: Proportion of sales in a marketplace that is claimed by a specific company or product.
criteria.reason: Understanding market share helps identify leading players within the systems software sector.

data_points.name: Total Revenue
data_points.description: Total sales generated from systems software products.

data_points.name: Unit Sales
data_points.description: Total number of software units sold.

key_points: Assess growth trends in market share over time.
Identify main competitors and their market positions.
Evaluate the impact of emerging technologies on market share.
Analyze regional differences in market share.
Consider potential mergers and acquisitions affecting market dynamics.

charts.usage: Visualize the market share distribution among top companies.
Compare market shares of different competitors over multiple quarters.

criteria.name: Product Innovation
criteria.description: Rate at which new features and technologies are implemented into product lines.
criteria.reason: Innovation drives competitiveness and relevance in the fast-evolving systems software landscape.

data_points.name: R&D Expenditure
data_points.description: Total spending on research and development activities.

data_points.name: Patents Filed
data_points.description: Number of patents filed in a given year.

key_points: Monitor the pace of new product releases.
Evaluate customer feedback on recent innovations.
Investigate partnerships enhancing innovation.
Review industry awards for innovative products.
Consider the lifecycle stage of existing products.

charts.usage: Show trends in R&D spending compared to revenue over time.
Highlight number of patents filed by competitors.

criteria.name: Customer Satisfaction
criteria.description: Level of satisfaction among users with the products and services offered.
criteria.reason: High customer satisfaction leads to better retention, referrals, and overall performance.
examples: Net Promoter Score (NPS), Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAT)

data_points.name: Churn Rates
data_points.description: Percentage of customers that stop using the software in a given time period.

key_points: Gather and analyze customer feedback regularly.
Identify common pain points across users.
Track changes in satisfaction over new product updates.
Benchmark against industry standards.
Engage with customers proactively to understand their needs.

charts.usage: Visualize correlation between survey scores and churn rates.
Feature comparisons based on multiple satisfaction metrics.

criteria.name: Infrastructure Scalability
criteria.description: Ability of systems software to grow and manage increased loads efficiently.
criteria.reason: Scalable systems software is essential for supporting growth in user base and data.

data_points.name: Load Capacity
data_points.description: Maximum load the software can handle effectively.

data_points.name: User Growth Rate
data_points.description: Percentage increase in user base within a defined period.

key_points: Assess current and projected loads against capacity.
Evaluate elasticity of resources in cloud environments.
Review case studies of scaling successes and failures.
Analyze performance under peak load conditions.
Plan for future scalability needs in product development.

charts.usage: Display historical load capacity against user growth.
Represent different load scenarios and their handling efficiency.

criteria.name: Security Compliance
criteria.description: Adherence to laws, regulations, and standards regarding data security and privacy.
criteria.reason: Maintaining compliance mitigates risks associated with data breaches and legal issues.

data_points.name: Incident Reports
data_points.description: Records of security incidents and breaches.

key_points: Regularly review and update compliance policies.
Conduct frequent audits to uncover gaps.
Implement training programs for employees.
Monitor industry changes in regulations.
Assess impact of compliance on customer trust.

charts.usage: Visualize compliance status across different departments or measures.
Compare incident reports before and after compliance measures.

criteria.name: Cost Efficiency
criteria.description: Evaluation of the cost relative to the benefits received from the systems software.
criteria.reason: Higher cost efficiency leads to better profit margins and competitive pricing.
examples: Cost per user, Total cost of ownership (TCO)

data_points.name: Operational Costs
data_points.description: Monthly and yearly expenses associated with the software.

data_points.name: Return on Investment (ROI)
data_points.description: Financial benefits derived from using the software.

key_points: Analyze fixed vs variable costs in operations.
Evaluate pricing models against competitors.
Identify cost-saving opportunities without sacrificing quality.
Regularly track ROI on extensive software investments.
Adjust strategy based on cost-benefit analysis results.

charts.usage: Visualize operational costs in comparison to revenue generated.
Display changes in cost efficiency over time.

criteria.name: Technical Support and Services
criteria.description: Quality and availability of support and professional services provided to customers.
criteria.reason: Strong support services enhance customer retention and satisfaction.
examples: Helpdesk response time, Availability of training programs

data_points.name: Response Time
data_points.description: Average time taken to resolve customer issues.

data_points.name: Customer Training Engagement
data_points.description: Participation rates in training programs offered.

key_points: Regularly survey customers on support satisfaction.
Track tickets resolution times for continuous improvement.
Benchmark support services against industry standards.
Analyze engagement metrics of training programs.
Implement feedback loops for support improvements.

charts.usage: Track changes in response times over a period.
Show distribution of support types and their resolution success.

criteria.name: Integration Capability
criteria.description: Ability of systems software to integrate with other software and platforms.
criteria.reason: Good integration capabilities add value by enhancing functionality and usability.
examples: API availability, Compatibility with other software

data_points.name: Number of Supported Integrations
data_points.description: Total number of third-party software integrations.

key_points: Map out essential software ecosystems requiring integration.
Evaluate customer needs for integrations.
Monitor performance and issues with existing integrations.
Investigate new technologies facilitating better integrations.
Review case studies of successful integrations.

charts.usage: Visualize the relationship between number of integrations and success rate.
Highlight the distribution of integration types.
